0.05.text: [Applause and music:  Thin Lizzy: "The boys are back in town"]

6.30.text: [Paul Ryan] Hello, everybody! Hello, everybody! Thank you. Thank you.

22.52.text: Thank you very much. Thank you. Hey, Wisconsin! Thank you. Thank you.

44.91.text: You are the great. Thanks so much. Thank you.

57.24.text: Mr. Chairman - Mr. Chairman, delegates, and fellow citizens:

65.40.text: I am honored by the support of this convention for vice president of the United States. [Cheers]

82.53.text: I accept the duty to help lead our nation out of a jobs crisis and back to prosperity –

89.42.text:
and I know we can do this.
[Applause]

96.88.text: I accept the calling of my generation to give our children the America that was given to us,

103.67.text: with opportunity for the young and security for the old – and I know that we are ready.

110.22.text: Our nominee is sure ready. His whole life - his whole life prepared him for this moment –

118.49.text: to meet serious challenges in a serious way, without excuses and idle words.

125.87.text: After four years of getting the run-around, America needs a turnaround,

130.64.text: and the man for the job is Governor Mitt Romney. [Applause]

148.04.text: I'm the newcomer to this campaign, so let me share a first impression.

154.71.text: I have never seen opponents so silent about their record,

160.05.text: and so desperate to keep their power.

165.86.text: They've run out of ideas. Their moment came and went.

171.85.text: Fear and division is all they've got left.

176.45.text: With all their attack ads, the president is just throwing away money –

181.52.text:
and he's pretty experienced at that.
[Laughter and applause]

193.72.text: You see, some people can't be dragged down by the usual cheap tactics,

200.16.text: because their character, ability, and plain decency are so obvious –

206.18.text:
and ladies and gentlemen, that is Mitt Romney.
[Applause]

219.39.text: For my part, your nomination is an unexpected turn.

224.80.text: It certainly came as news to my family, and I'd like you to meet them:

230.97.text: My best friend and wife Janna, our daughter Liza, and our boys Charlie and Sam. [Applause]

253.77.text: The kids are happy to see their grandma, who lives in Florida. There she is – my Mom, Betty. [Applause]

268.61.text: My Dad, a small-town lawyer, was also named Paul.

274.37.text: Until we lost him when I was 16, he was a gentle presence in my life.

280.74.text: I like to think he'd be proud of me and my sister and brothers, [Applause]

290.38.text: You know what? I'm sure proud of him and of where I come from, Janesville, Wisconsin. [Applause]

307.19.text: I live on the same block where I grew up.

309.67.text: We belong to the same parish where I was baptized. Janesville is that kind of place.

315.57.text: The people of Wisconsin have been good to me. I've tried to live up to their trust.

321.47.text: And now I ask those hardworking men and women, and millions like them across America,

327.48.text: to join our cause and get this country working again. [Applause]

342.73.text: When Governor Romney asked me to join the ticket, I said, "Let's get this done" –

347.92.text: and that is exactly, what we're going to do. [Applause]

360.17.text: President Barack Obama came to office during an economic crisis,

365.63.text: as he has reminded us a time or two. [Laughter]

373.22.text: and any fair measure of his record has to take that into account.

377.76.text: My home state voted for President Obama.

381.18.text: When he talked about change, many people liked the sound of it,

386.01.text: especially in Janesville, where we were about to lose a major factory.

391.46.text: A lot of guys I went to high school with worked at that GM plant.

395.57.text: Right there at that plant, candidate Obama said:

399.45.text: "I believe that if our government is there to support you ...

402.60.text: this plant will be here for another hundred years." That's what he said in 2008.

408.99.text: Well, as it turned out, that plant didn't last another year.

415.24.text: It is locked up and empty to this day.

419.18.text: And that's how it is in so many towns,

422.72.text: where the recovery that was promised is nowhere in sight.

427.61.text: Right now, 23 million men and women are struggling to find work.

435.36.text: Twenty-three million people, unemployed or underemployed.

440.58.text: Nearly one in six Americans is in poverty.

445.95.text: Millions of young Americans have graduated from college during the Obama presidency,

450.74.text: ready to use their gifts and get moving in life.

454.29.text: Half of them can't find the work they studied for, or any work at all.

466.00.text: why would the next four years be any different from the last four years? [Applause]

484.80.text: The first troubling sign came with the stimulus.

489.00.text: It was President Obama's first and best shot at fixing the economy,

493.54.text: at a time when he got everything he wanted under one-party rule.

499.03.text: It cost $831 billion – the largest one-time expenditure ever by our federal government.

507.16.text: It went to companies like Solyndra,

509.49.text: with their gold-plated connections, subsidized jobs, and make-believe markets.

515.18.text: The stimulus was a case of political patronage, corporate welfare,

529.47.text: You, you the American people of this country, were cut out of the deal.

536.45.text: What did the taxpayers get out of the Obama stimulus?

541.54.text: That money wasn't just spent and wasted – it was borrowed, spent, and wasted. [Applause]

557.38.text: Maybe the greatest waste of all was time.

562.77.text: Here we were, faced with a massive job crisis –

566.55.text: so deep that if everyone out of work stood in single file,

571.42.text: that unemployment line would stretch the length of the entire American continent.

578.25.text: You would think that any president, whatever his party,

581.47.text: would make job creation, and nothing else, his first order of economic business.

588.95.text: But this president didn't do that.

591.69.text: Instead, we got a long, divisive, all-or-nothing attempt

597.17.text: to put the federal government in charge of health care. [Booing]

606.34.text: Obamacare comes to more than two thousand pages of rules, mandates, taxes, fees,

613.34.text: and fines that have no place in a free country. [Applause] That's right. [Applause] That's right. [Applause]

652.64.text: You know what? The president has declared that the debate over government-controlled health care is over.

659.88.text: That will come as news to the millions of Americans who will elect Mitt Romney

681.39.text: And the biggest, coldest power play of all in Obamacare came at the expense of the elderly.

690.05.text: You see, even with all the hidden taxes to pay for the health care takeover,

695.65.text: even with the new law and new taxes on nearly a million small businesses,

702.56.text: the planners in Washington still didn't have enough money.

706.11.text: They needed more. They needed hundreds of billions more.

712.69.text: So, they just took it all away from Medicare.

716.12.text: Seven hundred and sixteen billion dollars, funneled out of Medicare by President Obama. [Booing]

725.21.text: An obligation we have to our parents and grandparents is being sacrificed,

729.98.text: all to pay for a new entitlement we didn't even ask for. [Applause]

742.79.text: The greatest threat to Medicare is Obamacare, and we're going to stop it. [Applause]

763.82.text: In Congress, when they take out the heavy books and wall charts about Medicare,

770.32.text: my thoughts go back to a house on Garfield Street in Janesville.

774.60.text: My wonderful grandma, Janet, had Alzheimer's and she moved in with Mom and me.

781.07.text: Though she felt lost at times, we did all the little things that made her feel loved.

787.11.text: We had help from Medicare, and it was there, just like it's there for my Mom today.

793.51.text: Medicare is a promise, and we will honor it.

797.45.text: A Romney-Ryan administration will protect and strengthen Medicare,

800.44.text: for my Mom's generation, for my generation, and for my kids and yours. [Applause]

824.02.text: So our opponents can consider themselves on notice.

828.71.text: In this election, on this issue, the usual posturing on the Left isn't going to work.

835.38.text: Mitt Romney and I know the difference between protecting a program, and raiding it.

840.03.text: Ladies and gentlemen, our nation needs this debate.

872.26.text: Obamacare, as much as anything else,

876.58.text: explains why a presidency that began with such anticipation

883.02.text: now comes to such a disappointing close.

887.00.text: It began with a financial crisis; it ends with a job crisis.

894.04.text: It began with a housing crisis they alone didn't cause;

898.40.text: it ends with a housing crisis they didn't correct. [Applause]

908.51.text: It began with a perfect Triple-A credit rating for the United States;

914.31.text: it ends with a downgraded America. [Booing]

921.42.text: It all started off with stirring speeches, Greek columns, the thrill of something new.

928.75.text: Now all that's left is a presidency adrift,

934.73.text: surviving on slogans that already seem tired,

938.73.text: grasping at a moment that has already passed,

942.78.text: like a ship trying to sail on yesterday's wind. [Applause]

954.67.text: You know, President Obama was asked not long ago to reflect

961.99.text: on any mistakes he might have made.

964.76.text: He said, well, "I haven't communicated enough." [laughter]

970.45.text: He said his job is to "tell a story to the American people" –

976.58.text: as if that's the whole problem here?

980.01.text: He needs to talk more, and we need to be better listeners? [Laughter]

985.79.text: Ladies and gentlemen, these past four years

989.67.text: we have suffered no shortage of words in the White House.

994.47.text: What's missing is leadership in the White House. [Applause]

1034.35.text: And the story -- and the story that Barack Obama does tell,

1042.11.text: forever shifting blame to the last administration, is getting old.

1047.70.text: The man assumed office almost four years ago –

1051.56.text: isn't it about time he assumed responsibility? [Applause]

1067.12.text: In this generation, a defining responsibility of government

1072.99.text: is to steer our nation clear of a debt crisis while there is still time.

1079.51.text: Back in 2008, candidate Obama called a $10 trillion national debt "unpatriotic" –

1087.56.text: serious talk from what looked to be a serious reformer.

1093.68.text: President Obama has added more debt than any other president before him,

1098.74.text: and more than all the troubled governments of Europe combined.

1103.13.text: One president, one term, $5 trillion in new debt. [booing]

1112.75.text: He created a bipartisan debt commission.

1117.13.text: They came back with an urgent report.

1120.37.text: He thanked them, sent them on their way, and then did exactly nothing.

1130.03.text: Republicans stepped up with good-faith reforms and solutions equal to the problems.

1139.24.text: By doing nothing – nothing except to dodge and demagogue the issue.

1144.80.text: So here we are, $16 trillion in debt and still he does nothing.

1151.50.text: In Europe, massive debts have put entire governments at risk of collapse,

1159.13.text: And all we have heard from this president and his team

1163.15.text: are attacks on anyone who dares to point out the obvious.

1168.96.text: They have no answer to this simple reality:

1174.14.text: We need to stop spending money we don't have. [Applause]

1199.46.text: My Dad used to say to me:

1202.92.text: "Son. You have a choice: You can be part of the problem, or you can be part of the solution."

1209.88.text: The present administration has made its choices.

1213.95.text: And Mitt Romney and I have made ours:

1216.83.text: Before the math and the momentum overwhelm us all,

1220.43.text: we are going to solve this nation's economic problems. [Applause]

1236.56.text: And I'm going to level with you: We don't have that much time.

1241.82.text: But if we are serious, and smart, and we lead, we can do this.

1247.81.text: After four years of government trying to divide up the wealth,

1250.61.text: we will get America creating wealth again. [Applause]

1256.39.text: With tax fairness and regulatory reform,

1259.98.text: we'll put government back on the side of the men and women who create jobs,

1264.99.text: and the men and women who need jobs.

1269.81.text: My Mom started a small business, and I've seen what it takes.

1275.49.text: Mom was 50 when my Dad died.

1278.87.text: She got on a bus every weekday for years,

1282.65.text: and rode 40 miles each morning to Madison.

1286.65.text: She earned a new degree and learned new skills to start her small business.

1291.59.text: It wasn't just a new livelihood. It was a new life.

1296.70.text: And it transformed my Mom from a widow in grief

1301.10.text: to a small businesswoman whose happiness wasn't just in the past.

1306.04.text: Her work gave her hope. It made our family proud.

1311.58.text: And to this day, my Mom is my role model. [Applause]

1349.22.text: Behind every small business, there's a story worth knowing.

1354.76.text: All the corner shops in our towns and cities,

1357.83.text: the restaurants, cleaners, gyms, hair salons, hardware stores –

1362.67.text: these didn't come out of nowhere.

1365.30.text: A lot of heart goes into each one.

1368.44.text: And if small businesspeople say they made it on their own,

1371.39.text: all they are saying is that nobody else worked seven days a week in their place.

1376.90.text: Nobody showed up in their place to open the door at five in the morning.

1380.66.text: Nobody did their thinking, and worrying, and sweating for them.

1385.27.text: After all that work, and in a bad economy,

1388.51.text: it sure doesn't help to hear from their president that government gets the credit.

1393.24.text: What they deserve to hear is the truth: Yes, you did build that. [Applause]

1418.31.text: We have a plan for a stronger middle class,

1422.00.text: with the goal of generating 12 million new jobs over the next four years.

1428.17.text: In a clean break -- in a clean break from the Obama years,

1432.02.text: and frankly from the years before this president,

1436.12.text: we will keep federal spending at 20 percent of GDP, or less.

1451.92.text: The choice -- the choice is whether to put hard limits on economic growth,

1457.36.text: or hard limits on the size of government, and we choose to limit government.  [Applause]

1470.60.text: I learned a good deal about economics, and about America,

1475.09.text: from the author of the Reagan tax reforms – the great Jack Kemp.  [Applause]

1486.18.text: What gave Jack that incredible enthusiasm was his belief in the possibilities of free people,

1492.70.text: in the power of free enterprise and strong communities to overcome poverty and despair.

1498.10.text: We need that same optimism right now.

1501.67.text: And in our dealings with other nations,

1504.81.text: a Romney-Ryan administration will speak with confidence and clarity.

1509.86.text: Whenever men and women rise up for their own freedom,

1514.01.text: they will know that the American president is on their side.  [Applause]

1527.04.text: Instead -- instead of managing American decline,

1532.22.text: leaving allies to doubt us and adversaries to test us, we will act in the conviction

1537.56.text: that the United States is still the greatest force for peace and liberty

1541.21.text: that this world has ever known. [Applause]

1561.43.text: President Obama is the kind of politician who puts promises on the record,

1569.17.text: and then calls that the record.

1573.50.text: But we are four years into this presidency.

1576.76.text: The issue is not the economy that Barack Obama inherited,

1582.31.text: not the economy that he envisions, but this economy that we are living.  [Applause]

1596.10.text: College graduates should not have to live out their 20s in their childhood bedrooms,

1601.67.text: staring up at fading Obama posters

1604.27.text: and wondering when they can move out and get going with life.  [Applause]

1637.42.text: Everyone -- everyone who feels stuck in the Obama economy is right to focus on the here and now.

1647.13.text: And I hope you understand this too, if you're feeling left out or passed by:

1653.84.text: You have not failed, your leaders have failed you.

1659.21.text: None of us -- none of us should have to settle for the best this administration offers:

1668.64.text: a dull, adventureless journey from one entitlement to the next,

1673.45.text: a government-planned life, a country where everything is free but us.

1680.74.text: Listen to the way we're spoken already to,  [Applause]

1693.21.text: as if everyone is stuck in some class or station in life,

1697.43.text: victims of circumstances beyond our control,

1700.52.text: with the government there to help us cope with our fate.

1704.05.text: It's the exact opposite of everything I learned growing up in Wisconsin,

1716.29.text: You know, when I was waiting tables, washing dishes, or mowing lawns for money,

1724.24.text: I never thought of myself as stuck in some station in life.

1728.64.text: I was on my own path, my own journey,

1731.41.text: an American journey where I could think for myself, decide for myself,

1738.83.text: That's what we do in this country.

1744.79.text: and I'll take it any day over the supervision and sanctimony of the central planners.  [Applause]

1762.44.text: By themselves - by themselves, the failures of one administration

1769.37.text: are not a mandate for a new administration.

1773.15.text: A challenger must stand on his own merits.

1777.13.text: He must be ready and worthy to serve in the office of president.

1781.54.text: We're a full generation apart, Governor Romney and I.

1785.97.text: And, in some ways, we're a little different.

1788.12.text: There are the songs on his iPod,

1789.79.text: which I've heard on the campaign bus and I've heard on many hotel elevators. [Laughter]

1803.30.text: He actually -- he actually urged me to play some of these songs at campaign rallies.

1806.95.text: I said: look, I hope it's not a deal-breaker Mitt,

1810.66.text: but my playlist starts with AC/DC, and ends with Zeppelin. [laughter and applause]

1822.59.text: A generation apart. A generation apart.

1827.68.text: But that doesn't matter, It makes us different, but not in any of the things that matter.

1835.23.text: Mitt Romney and I both grew up in the heartland,

1838.74.text: and we know what places like Wisconsin and Michigan look like when times are good,  [Applause]

1846.20.text: We know what these communities look like when times are good,

1849.71.text: when people are working, when families are doing more than just getting by.

1854.44.text: And we know it can be that way again.

1858.64.text: mine mainly in public service, his mostly in the private sector.

1863.32.text: He helped start businesses and turn around failing ones,

1865.78.text: and by the way, being successful in business – that's a good thing. [Applause]

1889.62.text: Mitt has not only succeeded, but succeeded where others could not.

1898.22.text: at a time when a great institution was collapsing under the weight of bad management,

1903.14.text: overspending, and corruption – sounds familiar, doesn't it? [Laughter]

1909.36.text: He was the Republican governor of a state

1912.00.text: where almost nine in ten legislators are Democrats,

1915.34.text: and yet he balanced the budget without raising taxes.

1919.84.text: Unemployment went down, household incomes went up,

1923.52.text: and Massachusetts, under Governor Mitt Romney, saw its credit rating upgraded.  [Applause]

1938.18.text: Mitt and I also go to different churches.

1941.79.text: But in any church, the best kind of preaching is done by example.

1948.18.text: And I've been watching that example.  [Applause]

1953.02.text: The man who will accept your nomination tomorrow

1956.26.text: is prayerful and faithful and honorable.

1960.15.text: Not only a defender of marriage, he offers an example of marriage at its best.

1966.20.text: Not only a fine businessman, he's a fine man,

1971.89.text: worthy of leading this optimistic and good-hearted country.

1977.09.text: Our faiths come together in a same moral creed.

1982.95.text: We believe that in every life there is goodness; for every person, there is hope.

1990.89.text: Each one of us was made for a reason, bearing the image and likeness of the Lord of Life.  [Applause]

2015.27.text: We have responsibilities, one to another – we do not each face the world alone.

2022.54.text: And the greatest of all responsibilities, is that of the strong to protect the weak.

2027.95.text: The truest measure of any society is how it treats those

2032.68.text: who cannot defend or care for themselves.  [Applause]

2040.38.text: Each of these moral ideas -- each of these moral ideas is essential to democratic government –

2048.18.text: to the rule of law, to life in a humane and decent society.

2053.16.text: They are the moral creed of our country, as powerful in our time,

2057.73.text: as on the day of America's founding.

2063.22.text: and sometimes, even presidents need reminding,

2067.72.text: that our rights come from nature and God, not from government.  [Applause]

2086.12.text: The founding generation secured those rights for us,

2089.67.text: and in every generation since, the best among us have defended our freedoms.

2094.48.text: They are protecting us right now.

2096.53.text: We honor them and all our veterans, and we thank them.  [Applause]

2109.51.text: The right that makes all the difference now, is the right to choose our own leaders.

2117.04.text: And you are entitled to the clearest possible choice,

2123.71.text: because the time for choosing is drawing near.

2130.28.text: We will not duck the tough issues, we will lead.

2133.06.text: We will not spend four years blaming others, we will take responsibility.

2138.39.text: We will not try to replace our founding principles, we will reapply our founding principles.  [Applause]

2147.21.text: The work ahead will be hard.

2149.52.text: These times demand the best of all of us – all of us, but we can do this.

2155.64.text: We can do this. Together, we can do this.

2160.19.text: We can get this country working again.

2162.48.text: We can get this economy growing again.

2165.36.text: We can make the safety net safe again.

2169.98.text: Whatever your political party, let's come together for the sake of our country.

2177.44.text: Let's give this effort everything we have.

2180.11.text: Let's see this thing all the way through.

2184.90.text: Thank you, and God bless you all.  [Applause] Thank you.  [Applause]

2202.00.text: [Music: Thin Lizzy: "The boys are back in town"]
